Posts.Content: Hi, Just wanted to say it is really helpful to read this thread and hear from you all.  I am seeing my chemo oncologist on Monday to hear what's next as I took part in the Optima trial and have been told that I won't be doing chemo after all which is great news, and I know from my surgeon - mastectomy, recon and axillary clearance, that the next stop is Radio Therapy.  Not sure what happens next, if I get passed onto another oncologist for that or what, or how long it is all going to take to get started, or what sort of treatment they will have in mind so I wanted to look and see what the next steps will be.  I am only 5 weeks post op so not lifting my arm up above my head yet, so I assume that it will be a few weeks before I start, but it is really, really helpful to know what might be next. I have been back to work a little since the op and hope to phase back into full time over the next couple of weeks, does anyone know how feasible working is whilst having RT, I am also a single mum - see profile.  I want to get back to work, and need to financially, but also want to make sure I don't over face myself and go backwards, this weekend has been a bit of a case in point as I have been more emotional and teary than ever, and sore. Posts.Content: Hi. I’m also a few weeks further on and whilst I am just post mastectomy now - still only a matter of days since I really remember that awful time during the diagnosis process. It is very scary and no matter how many people tell you they have or know someone who has been through it and they are fine now. That doesn’t really help. Because this is happening to you and it is scary right now it is terrifying and it doesn’t seem to leave your brain it just lurks there. Meanwhile you maybe frantically trying to get things done and organised before treatment starts so it is stressful too on a practical level.  I could say you’ll be fine and it gets better - it does sort of or at least it changes. But what might help too is to say; be really kind to yourself. Let people you know and love know how you are feeling and if you can let them listen and support you. Also. You are allowed to be scared. Giving yourself permission to feel this way might make it more manageable. You aren’t alone though. And I really hope that you see the clinic again soon to find out your next steps. The limbo stops then for a bit. Ohh and if you need to. Call the breast care nurses at your breast clinic. They know your diagnosis, your situation, and what the care might look like a bit. They might be able to help.  Go well and take care xxx

Posts.Content: Dear Henty, I realise that today has gone by and you will have had your pre-med, sorry for not coming on line sooner. Been a bit of a couple of days for me, just logistics, coming back from Northumberland and then hospital appointments today but really sorry not to have been in touch sooner. Hope all went really well for pre-op.  I don't know about you but when your surgery is jumped on you like that it is so scary and then you have to get through the pre-op because for some reason the operation is supposed to happen fast which makes it scarier and more important. I hope it all went well because I bet you were worried.. If you can and like you I had my pre-op just two days before the op, please try and do something tomorrow which will help you breathe.. I went to the beach.  My go to place, but do whatever helps, bake, walk, talk, run whatever, it doesn't matter, just try and get some time where you know you are being fed, restored, replenished and you are not just giving out to others.  ( I do know the other people matter in our lives right now, more probably than ever, but I'm afraid you also need time for you right now, just to get you through.)  Despite the operation being a really huge thing for me, it was fine, the aneasthetist was amazing - do you know their job is to keep you asleep and then make sure you are pain free - pretty cool if you ask me, talk to her/him and she should reassure you.  The operation went well for me and I was so surprised that I still felt something in that area when I woke up, it will still be your skin and your body, it is just the implant that is new.  In my case too the ward knew precisely what they were dealing with which was so reassuring.  You will be ok.  That is not to say that too this is huge and I am just beginning to acknowledge that too.  Hopefully they will tell you to take it really easy for a good few weeks.  I am still not allowed to drive and I am four weeks in.  This is good time, time to not fret (ok I have been but realise it isn't helpful), and try and let people look after you, while your body and mind and emotions begin to get to grip with it all. I will be thinking of you on Thursday, do you know if you are morning or afternoon and I will say a prayer too.  Tight hugs, and gentle ones later.  Hope you are ok. xxx

Posts.Content: H Sunshine 19, Sorry it has taken me a little while to get back to you, I am now in the most wonderful place in the world - Holy Island, I may post something about it later.  It is bright sunshine and the sea all around and for the first time in months I can almost breathe.  Although it still hurts a bit when I do - recon still a little sore.  Which leads me onto your question. I had implant recon which seems to have gone really well.  I'm quite slight so tummy flap wasn't an option and they don't do the back one in my hospital which would have meant going further afield, and a more extensive operation, and I just wasn't sure really.  So implant it was.  As I am not huge, I think the surgeon placed it under rather than over my pectoral muscle and it is also sitting in a pig skin sling inside - can't remember the name of it, but basically that is there to support the implant.  I am stunned by how well it looks really.  It is my skin over the implant and apart from the fact I have no nipple (tumour was right under it) and some really very considerable bruising it looks pretty fab.  In fact last night I went out wearing a dress which shows a little cleavage and honestly noone would know. It isn't quite the same shape or size as my other breast when I am naked, and of course it feels different, but not that bad actually now that I am getting used to it.  It does take a while to get used to it though. Sounds like you have really been finding it hard, I am not surprised it is pretty tough.  Don't forget a few weeks ago the world looked normal, now you are living with having cancer, treatment, a major operation, the loss of your breast, a whole host of other things and a lot of unknown stuff too as you wait for diagnosis, op date, op, op results etc.  This is pretty huge.  I know there are some incredibly brave woment out there, and most of them seem to come online here sometimes too which is lovely, but I don't feel brave most of the time and I doubt many of them do either.  (there may be a few super-women, who do and I would love to know how). Even when I think I am doing well, I flunk it.  Yesterday despite managing to travel all the way up to Northumberland by train and bus, I then lost my purse with everything in it, cards, cash and even my implant registration number card - hellllllllp.  Retraced my steps about twenty times, called the bus company, went into every shop, pub and hotel in Bamburgh and it still hasn't turned up.  I felt so scared, and so vulnerable, especially alone, without a car and no money.  I also have spent about a day beating myself up about it, but I think it is time I stopped.  The people in the village I have to say were really kind and I managed because of them and the bank being really helpful too. So be as kind to yourself as you can, if there is anything you can do to give yourself a bit of a break, please do, if anyone offers you help and you can take it, do, and be gentle on yourself as well if you can - Oh and eating - one thing I have found that helps is eating without realising your doing it if you know what I mean, sort of having some very small nibbly things about, so it isn't a meal as such, it's just you walk past a small dish of seeds/nuts/dried fruit/mini chocolate eggs/biscuits/cut up chocolate brownie/cheese whatever you fancy and as you do you sort of take a bit and eat it.  It has worked for me, might do for you, and keep the tea flowing too, fluids help and a good cup of tea can go a long way. Hope this is all helpful. Have a very lovely Easter - oh hot cross buns and butter - that is another one for the nibbling dish. Blessings and hugs

Posts.Content: Hi Henty,  I do know just what you mean. You can feel very abandoned at times. Even the better units don’t necessarily give the support we need, especially emotionally. Which is why we are here.  Advice for what it’s worth. Give the breast unit a call first thing tomorrow morning or even today and leave a message for them to call you back. No harm in chasing up your referral.  Dont feel you’re making a fuss either. This is huge. Sometimes it makes sense, sometimetines it makes no sense at all. I often find when people tell me that I’ll be fine that’s when it makes least sense if all. Because a diagnosis doesn’t feel fine. It feels and it is life changing. Even if at the end of the day the way it changes our lives is not as terrible as our fears.  Sleep. Don’t worry about it. I found I was awake in the early hours and that was it. Do you have a journal of any sort. It can be really useful to have a dedicated place to write down your thoughts and feelings and questions. I have all my appointments in mine too with all my questions for the medics/nurses and the notes I make when at appointments. That way it is all in the one place I need them and I’m less likely to lose the info which is really reassuring as I am not the most organised of people. I also have my to do lists in there and looking back it is surprising how much I got done in those dark hours of the night. Banking, admin, washing and if you need to chat in the night there is an online group for those not sleeping too.  When it comes to food. Also get that. I lost a load of weight during the diagnosis period. Couldn’t eat either. Don’t beat yourself up about it but let yourself eat those things you might just want. Oddly my snack was cereal with ice cold milk and cream. Something I haven’t eaten since I was a kid! I’m warning myself off it now as ever since the op - full mastectomy, lymph node clearance and reconstruction my appetite has come back.  Anything else you need or want to chat about just go online. We’ll get back to you and if you can tell anyone in physical life do. It really helps to have people around you.  Hope you get news of your referral soon.  Xx

Posts.Content: Hi. Hoping this is ok to post. I have just had my post op appointment and I’m in a bit of a muddle emotionally and logically so I hope someone might be able to help.  Operation went well Tumors though sizeable - over 5cm were removed in the mastectomy and only a few of my lymph nodes were positive although I did have full axillary clearance. However they are recommending chemo followed by radio therapy before long term hormone therapy and I am not sure exactly why.  I have no breast on that side apparently this type of cancer - invasive lobular - is unlikely to appear in the other breast and is very resistant to chemo therapy so if the cancer is gone why do I need further treatment. Is there a higher risk of further cancer in the same area or elsewhere or am I now cancer free- which is what the surgeon seemed to say when he told me. In fact it was sort of a session where he told me he had done his job and whilst I still have to return to the clinic to have my dressings changed that’s it I am now not their concern. I see the oncologist on Monday.  I am really confused emotionally as I feel like I should be celebrating but I’m actually rather bewildered and feel a bit lost as I don’t think I’m under the breast cancer care unit any more. Meanwhile the surgery wounds are healing well but the bruising is still huge and very painful and my arm feels as if the skin is in a cheese grater. I am not allowed to drive for another four weeks and can’t go back to work for a while either.   Sorry I sound as if I am feeling sorry for myself but I just wondered if anyone out there had any advice.  Thanks xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn, Thank you so much again for that, so answers to questions. I am 50, in overall good health although I have arthritis, and migraines, which I control as much as possible. That said in November of last year I was admitted to hospital with secondary sepsis following a UTI which has been reoccurring every 3-5 weeks since - something that does worry me if I have chemo as my white blood count will struggle to cope with any underlying infection. I am also a single mum to an 18yr old son and a 16yr old son with autism - both of whom are doing their exams this summer.  I also work, full time until March, but the company is having to make cut backs so it is part time at the minute.  There is no provision for sick pay, so it is statuary which doesn't go far with sons.  Whilst I am working I will continue to get working tax and child tax credits which will help. Also my job relys on my memory as I am an auctioneer and valuer of fine art and antiques so remembering what things are, and their likely worth is pretty vital to my work and when on the rostrum I need to stay really on the ball to keep the bidding on track, and me on track with it - so working with Chemo and the likely effects on my brain even short term is a difficult thing to see working.  In fact, I suspect if I react badly to the chemo, and have to take substantial time off work it is likely I will lose my job.  It is only a tiny business and they really can't afford to carry passengers. I owe it to my sons to do my best to make sure I stay healthy long term, but staying as an effective mother in the short to medium term seems even more important at the moment. As for decisions I have made, well I have made some huge mistakes in my life, but know I am not perfect, so sort of get on with what is and try and sort things out as best I can.  Life is messy, rather than predictable in my world.  Usually just as you get one thing sorted out - eg clearing up cat or dog sick the cieling starts to crumble on your head in the other corner of the room - not just an analogy, that did actually happen, and I still have the hole in the ceiling to prove it - I will sort that out at some time when I am aloud to lift my arm above my head again. - however I digress. Predict doesn't seem to differentiate for different types of Breast Cancer - eg ductal or lobular, so it can't factor that in, however apparently according to my surgical consultant at the breast clinic ILC is supposedly very resistant to chemo, so that is where I am taking that from, and it was confirmed by my oncologist, so the predict tool percentage is likely to be optomistic in my case.  Also I have been asked to join a blind trial where if I were tested (and there is no way to ask to be tested rather than not as it is a blind trial) the trial information reads that 'Most patients in Group 2 (those tested) wiill not have chemotherapy and can go straight to hormone therapy', suggesting that most patents in the trial in total won't benefit from chemo. Your earlier reply over the weekend was so helpful, but I take Lynn's point too.  Still veering a bit wildly between the two options, so any further insights would be really brilliant.  Thank you so much. Sophie / Pollydog xxx Been feeling knackered from the surgery and not great anyway, but I suspect that that has more to do with anxiety and everything else than being a 'real' thing, just psychosomatic.
Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: Dear Carolyn.  I really appreciate you taking the time and energy in this. You have no idea how much your input is really helping to get my thoughts in order and see things in a more rational way.  Ok timeline. Recurrent UTI started in October last year. Was on wrong antibiotics and was admitted to hospital in November with secondary sepsis.  Then after Christmas last year 2018 noticed breast change. Diagnosed mid Feb this year. Mastectomy and reconstruction March this year. Meanwhile diagnosed with and treated for number of UTIs recurring every 2-4 weeks.  MRI bone scan and Ct done prior to breast surgery as biopsy suggested cancer in lymph nodes. Biopsies done 7th Feb this year.  Surgery end of March this year. Histology results say ILC stage II ER+ with 2 lymph nodes positive.  Really don’t know if I can keep this family running in the short term with chemo effects and in all honesty job is precarious as company struggling so to abandon them now may seal all our fates. Definitely mine and can’t survive financially with the boys if I lose my job. Don’t mind about long term so much as boys will be more independent. Also trial sends most people tested straight to hormone/radio which suggests more info gives negative benefit for chemo. Sorry to agonise publicly but really really appreciate your help.  Why does the UTI make you think chemo better option btw?  Thank you.  Polly Dog hugs as she’s home.  Xxx
Posts.Title: Chemo or not to chemo invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: Dear Carolyn  I can’t tell you how much having you take the time and the trouble and the energy to reply so fully means. Thank you. I have spent a good few hours thinking about what you’ve said and I really recognise the ‘unscientific’ bit. It makes all too familiar sense to me. The science is helpful too.  I think however much I might want to run away from this - I told you I’m not brave- my body has been telling me there is something wrong for a while. I have told the oncologist and asked my go about it but apart from the recurrent UTI there is nothing tangible. Is it something to worry about - maybe not. But is it something to ignore in a decision about treatment ? - definitely not.  Scared as I am then I think I’m going to decide to go for the chemo trial. I will sit with the decision over the weekend and see how it feels. But I’m hoping the agonising over it is over and I can put my energies into rallying the support I may need. Work colleagues to help my addled brain, school and caring support to help the boys, and making sure the budgets as tight as can be etc. Going through chemo might not be easy for this little family but we will find a way. We always do. Thank you Carolyn. Your rambles are never rambles but always really helpful.  You take care.  Hugs Sophie xx

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn, Thank you for that.  To be honest the best I can do I think is the trial they are offering, as they haven't mentioned the Oncofocus and I have asked about further tests and more targeted therapies based on the tumour itself which really means its not available to me.  I had been coming round to accepting that chemo might be the way to go, based on all the brilliant advice I have had from you and everyone else here on line and talking at home.  Having sat with the decision I have decided to go for the trial and signed the papers this morning, which means I should hear if I am having chemo (most likely) or not - if the tumour is a part of the test group and it is better for me to go straight to hormone therapy.in two weeks time.  If it is chemo then I start on Wednesday 1st May.  Scared, but I think it is the right decision and it was reassuring that the Dr and Nurse said so too, they obviously hadn't been able to say before, but really felt that I should take the trial. I do wish that the medicine was a bit further ahead and more available for everyone to have more targetted therapies, but maybe, this trial will help that move forward. Thank you so much honey for all the support, and help and advice. Have a lovely Easter if I don't post before, I am traiining it and bussing it up to Northumberland as it is one of my favourite places in the world. Love and Hugs Sophie xx
